study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether N-(2,3-dihydroxypropyl)-valine (2,3-diHOPr-Val) could serve as a reliable biomarker for external dietary exposure to glycidol esters.
results_summary: The study demonstrated that 2,3-diHOPr-Val levels increased significantly in response to glycidol exposure, confirming its utility as a biomarker. The adduct levels followed expected formation and removal kinetics, with low interindividual variability.
population_specificity: 11 healthy participants
effective_dosage: 36 g of palm fat daily (containing 8.7 mg glycidol/kg), individual doses between 2.7 and 5.2 µg/kg body weight per day

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of increasing Lysine and Valine levels on the growth performance of nursery pigs, specifically identifying optimal Valine-to-Lysine ratios.
results_summary: The study found that increasing Valine-to-Lysine ratios improved average daily gain (ADG), average daily feed intake (ADFI), and gain-to-feed ratio (G:F), with optimal Valine requirements estimated between 63% and 74% of Lysine depending on the response criteria.
population_specificity: Nursery pigs (PIC 327 × 1,050) initially weighing 6.5–6.7 kg.
effective_dosage: SID Val:Lys ratios of 50% to 85%, with SID Lys concentration at 1.24%.
study_duration: 28 days (with specific analysis periods of 0–14 days and overall 28 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal standardized ileal digestible valine-to-lysine (SID Val:Lys) ratio for growth performance in 25- to 45-kg pigs under commercial conditions.
results_summary: The study found that increasing SID Val:Lys ratios improved average daily gain (ADG) and feed efficiency (G:F), with maximum ADG achieved at 73.0% SID Val:Lys and 99% of maximum G:F achieved at 63.2% SID Val:Lys. The best-fitting models for ADG and G:F were quadratic polynomial (QP), indicating dose-dependent effects.
population_specificity: Gilts (young female pigs) weighing 25-45 kg.
effective_dosage: Experiment 1: 59.0-75.5% SID Val:Lys; Experiment 2: 57.0-78.0% SID Val:Lys.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the dipeptide gamma-l-glutamyl-l-valine (γ-EV) could reduce inflammation and sepsis in an LPS-induced mouse model.
results_summary: γ-EV reduced pro-inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-6, IL-1β) in plasma and small intestine and suppressed inflammatory signaling by inhibiting JNK and IκBα phosphorylation, suggesting antisepsis effects.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice with LPS-induced sepsis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether l-valine enhances host immunity by increasing macrophage phagocytosis and its potential as a therapy for bacterial infections.
results_summary: The study found that l-valine elevated macrophage phagocytosis, reducing pathogen loads in infected tissues, including Klebsiella pneumoniae, Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Staphylococcus aureus. This effect was mediated through activation of the PI3K/Akt1 pathway and increased NO production via arginase inhibition.
population_specificity: Mice infected with Klebsiella pneumoniae and other bacterial strains.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of various transdermal enhancement strategies (iontophoresis, microneedles, and their combination) for delivering the peptide KPV (containing Valine) across human skin.
results_summary: KPV showed negligible permeation via passive diffusion but significantly increased delivery with microneedles (4.4 μg/cm²/h). Combining iontophoresis and microneedles further enhanced permeation (35-fold increase) and skin retention (10-fold increase).
population_specificity: Dermatomed human skin (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: Not specified (concentration varied as part of the study parameters).
study_duration: Not specified (duration of current application varied as part of the study parameters).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of different Valine-to-Lysine ratios on sow and piglet performance, specifically focusing on milk fat content and litter weight.
results_summary: A Val:Lys ratio of 1.1:1 increased milk fat at 7, 21, and 28 days but also increased backfat loss at weaning. Dietary regimes (Flat or Phased) with varying Val:Lys ratios improved litter weight at weaning compared to the control.
population_specificity: Multiparous sows during lactation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the chiral recognition ability and temperature-triggered switchable helix-sense properties of a synthesized polymer (PPAA-Val) derived from l-valine ethyl ester.
results_summary: PPAA-Val exhibited reversible helix-sense switching in chloroform upon heating and cooling, maintained over six cycles, and demonstrated high chiral recognition ability for specific racemic compounds when used as a chiral stationary phase in HPLC. The helical backbone was essential for chiral recognition, as its destruction eliminated this property.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of increasing leucine concentrations on the response of young piglets to dietary valine.
results_summary: Increasing dietary valine content improved daily weight gain, water and protein retention, and feed conversion efficiency, while higher leucine levels reduced feed intake and growth, particularly at lower valine levels. Supplementing low-valine feed with additional valine largely mitigated the negative effects of excess leucine.
population_specificity: Large White×Landrace entire male pigs, 44 days old, mean starting weight of 13.5 kg.
effective_dosage: Digestible valine concentrations of 11.9, 10.1, 8.3, 6.6, and 4.8 g/kg; leucine levels of 23, 45, and 67 g/kg.
interactions: Interaction between valine and leucine levels noted, with excess leucine reducing feed intake and growth, especially at lower valine levels.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether the BDNF Val66Met polymorphism (involving Valine) is associated with female sexual dysfunction (FSD) in patients with major depressive disorder (MDD) treated with SSRIs.
results_summary: The study found no significant association between BDNF Val66Met polymorphism and FSD overall, but it was significantly associated with lubrication disorder in patients treated with SSRIs. The prevalence of FSD was 31.6%, and problematic marriage was more frequent in the FSD group.
population_specificity: 95 female patients with MDD receiving SSRI treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of varying standardized ileal digestible (SID) valine:lysine ratios on the performance, milk composition, and plasma indices of lactating sows.
results_summary: Increasing the SID valine:lysine ratio improved sow feed intake, reduced back fat loss, and enhanced piglet growth and plasma valine concentrations. Optimal ratios were identified as 88% for minimizing back fat loss and 113% for maximizing piglet growth rate.
population_specificity: 32 Large White × Landrace lactating sows (parity 1.82 ± 0.62, body weight 219.78 ± 7.15 kg).
effective_dosage: 63%, 83%, 103%, or 123% SID valine:lysine ratios in corn-soybean meal-based diets.
study_duration: From day 107 of gestation until day 28 of lactation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Bacillus subtilis mutants could effectively supply Valine to piglets and improve their growth performance and blood amino acid concentrations.
results_summary: The study found that Bacillus subtilis mutants did not significantly improve growth performance or blood Valine levels compared to wild-type strains or negative controls, with only a transient increase in plasma Valine observed in one experiment.
population_specificity: Piglets (initial weights: 9.1±1.1 kg and 15.0±1.1 kg)
effective_dosage: 0.63 or 0.69 standardized ileal digestible (SID) Val : Lys ratios

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the industrial applications of D-valine and explore microbial preparation methods for its production.
results_summary: The study highlights D-valine's extensive industrial uses, including as an intermediate in agricultural pesticides, veterinary antibiotics, and pharmaceuticals, and its role in cell culture. Microbial preparation methods for D-valine are identified as promising due to their high stereo selectivity and environmental benefits.
population_specificity: Not specified (industrial and clinical applications)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the antialgal activity of L-valine against Microcystis aeruginosa and its effects on microcystin-LR (MC-LR) release and synthesis.
results_summary: L-valine showed strong antialgal activity against Microcystis aeruginosa, causing cell damage, chlorophyll decrease, and rapid dissipation. It also promoted MC-LR release and synthesis, though it dissipated faster than L-lysine.
population_specificity: Microcystis aeruginosa (cyanobacteria)
study_duration: 2 days (primary effects observed within this period)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the anti-inflammatory effects of γ-glutamyl valine (γ-EV) in intestinal epithelial cells and a mouse model of intestinal inflammation.
results_summary: γ-EV reduced pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-8, IL-6, IL-1β) and increased IL-10 in vitro, and ameliorated colitis symptoms in mice, acting via CaSR and β-arrestin2 pathways.
population_specificity: Intestinal epithelial cells (Caco-2) and mice with DSS-induced colitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the Met68BDNF allele (analogous to human Met66BDNF) increases the severity of alcohol abuse disorders and if Valine68BDNF overexpression or tropomyosin receptor kinase B activation can reverse compulsive alcohol intake.
results_summary: Met68BDNF mice exhibited excessive alcohol consumption and compulsive drinking despite negative consequences, which was reversed by Valine68BDNF overexpression in the ventromedial prefrontal cortex or systemic administration of the tropomyosin receptor kinase B agonist LM22A-4.
population_specificity: Transgenic mice carrying the Met68BDNF allele.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal standardized ileal digestible valine to lysine ratio for pigs of varying weight ranges fed low CP diets supplemented with crystalline amino acids.
results_summary: The study found that increasing the valine to lysine ratio improved average daily gain (ADG) and feed efficiency (G:F) in pigs across different weight ranges, with optimal ratios varying slightly by weight group. Serum urea nitrogen (SUN) levels decreased with higher valine to lysine ratios, indicating improved nitrogen utilization.
population_specificity: Pigs weighing 26-119 kg (Duroc × Landrace × Large White crossbreeds).

study_goal: The study aimed to evaluate the tolerance of laying hens for excessive L-valine (L-val) supplementation and its effects on laying performance, egg quality, serum free amino acids, immune function, and antioxidant enzyme activities.
results_summary: L-val supplementation up to 4 g/kg diet did not negatively affect laying performance, egg quality, immune function, or antioxidant enzyme activities. Serum albumin and glucose levels peaked at 2.0 g/kg, while serum free valine increased up to 2.0 g/kg and then decreased linearly.
population_specificity: HyLine Brown laying hens (40 to 47 weeks of age)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if heterologous cyclic dipeptides, including cyclo(valine-valine) (cVV), could repress Vibrio cholerae virulence factor production.
results_summary: The study found that cVV inhibited virulence factor production in V. cholerae by a ToxR-dependent process, repressing the virulence regulator aphA independently of known regulatory genes. The results suggest that cyclic dipeptides like cVV have potential as therapeutics for cholera treatment.
population_specificity: Vibrio cholerae (bacterial culture model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the decomposition products of L-valine when exposed to nonthermal plasma and propose mechanisms for its breakdown.
results_summary: L-valine decomposed into acetone, formic acid, acetic acid, threo-methylaspartic acid, erythro-methylaspartic acid, and pyruvic acid after plasma treatment, with concentrations dependent on exposure time. The study also identified potential DNA-damaging radicals formed during the process.
population_specificity: In vitro (L-valine solutions in water and phosphate buffer)
study_duration: Time-dependent plasma treatment (exact duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of replacing animal protein sources with crystalline amino acids, including Valine, on growth performance in young pigs.
results_summary: Increasing Valine-to-Lysine ratios improved average daily gain and feed intake, with optimal performance observed at 64.7% Val:Lys. Deleting Valine from the diet negatively impacted growth performance compared to the control.
population_specificity: 7- to 12-kg pigs (PIC TR4 × 1050) postweaning.
effective_dosage: Valine levels tested at 57.4%, 59.9%, 62.3%, 64.7%, 67.2%, and 69.6% of Lysine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify novel components of the peritrophic matrix (PM) in lepidopteran larvae, specifically valine-rich midgut proteins (MsVmps), as potential targets for insecticides.
results_summary: The study identified three valine-rich midgut proteins (MsVmps) in Manduca sexta larvae, which are loosely associated with the PM and highly O-glycosylated. MsVmp1 was found to be secreted into the ectoperitrophic space in feeding larvae, suggesting a role in digestive tract function and potential as an insecticide target.
population_specificity: Tobacco hornworm (Manduca sexta) larvae

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the rate and extent to which L-BAIBA appeared in human plasma after oral ingestion.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Valine's effects, only mentioning the study design and population.
population_specificity: Six males and six females.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a diamine derived from L-valine could efficiently form molecular gelators via reaction with succinic anhydride, enabling room-temperature gelation without conventional thermal treatment.
results_summary: The study found that different polymorphic fibrillar networks formed depending on the gel preparation method, with significant differences in thermal stability, thixotropic behavior, and dye release. In situ synthesis-gelation also enabled gel formation in media like oleic acid, which couldn't be jellified by conventional methods.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the clinical impact of valine supplementation on HCV viral load and its potential to support interferon therapy in patients with HCV-related advanced liver cirrhosis.
results_summary: Valine administration improved fatigue, reduced hepatic fibrosis indexes and serum α-fetoprotein levels, and significantly decreased HCV RNA levels, leading to successful HCV eradication with subsequent interferon β therapy.
population_specificity: A single patient with HCV-related advanced liver cirrhosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and physiological effects of AXA1665, a novel amino acid composition including Valine, on hepatic and muscle physiology in cirrhosis patients.
results_summary: AXA1665 increased plasma concentrations of constituent amino acids, improved branched-chain AA-to-aromatic AA ratios, reduced plasma ammonia levels, and enhanced body composition and frailty indices in cirrhosis patients. The supplement was safe and well-tolerated.
population_specificity: Subjects with Child-Pugh A and B cirrhosis.
study_duration: Two 15-day periods separated by a 14-day washout.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the associations between the MTHFR C677T polymorphism (which involves a valine-to-alanine mutation) and various diseases, focusing on its impact on homocysteine levels and potential nutritional interventions.
results_summary: The study found that the MTHFR C677T polymorphism results in reduced enzyme activity, leading to elevated homocysteine levels, which is a risk factor for cardiovascular diseases. Nutritional supplementation with vitamin B12 and folic acid was suggested to mitigate these effects.
population_specificity: Global populations with varying geography and ethnicity, focusing on individuals with the MTHFR C677T polymorphism.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the role of valine in sickle cell anemia, specifically how its substitution for glutamic acid in hemoglobin leads to disease pathology and potential therapeutic interventions.
results_summary: The study found that valine substitution in hemoglobin causes reduced solubility and polymerization under deoxygenated conditions, leading to erythrocyte deformation. It also mentioned alternative therapies like phytomedicines but did not directly assess valine's therapeutic efficacy.
population_specificity: Individuals with sickle cell anemia (genetically inherited "SS" individuals).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-neuroinflammatory effects and BBB-crossing ability of ultrasmall 2D vanadium carbide quantum dots (V2C QDs) in treating neuroinflammation-based brain diseases.
results_summary: V2C QDs demonstrated effective BBB-crossing ability, inhibited multiple inflammatory pathways, reduced oxidative stress, and prevented learning and memory impairment in mice. They significantly suppressed microglia and astrocyte activation and lowered inflammatory cytokine production.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice stimulated by lipopolysaccharide.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of MXene-coated carbon papers compared to heat-treated carbon papers for improving the performance of vanadium redox flow batteries (VRFBs).
results_summary: The study found that MXene-coated carbon papers achieved comparable vanadium reaction rates and diffusion coefficients to heat-treated carbon papers, with similar energy efficiency and discharge capacity retention over 150 cycles. The MXene coating demonstrated chemical stability, broadening its potential applications for carbon electrode treatments.
population_specificity: Not applicable (study focused on electrode materials for batteries, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the structural and electrical properties of organic-inorganic nanocomposites enriched with vanadium nanoparticles and their potential applications in electronic devices.
results_summary: The study found that vanadium oxide nanoparticles transformed into V2O3 and V8C7 phases under pyrolysis, influencing the material's electrical properties, including semiconductor-to-metal transitions and AC conduction mechanisms. The nanocomposites exhibited distinct behaviors suitable for applications in negatronic devices and electronic components.
population_specificity: Not applicable (material science study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether caffeic acid-vanadium metal polyphenol nanoparticles (CA-V NPs) could mitigate ischemia-reperfusion injury in skin flap transplantation by reducing oxidative stress and inflammation.
results_summary: CA-V NPs demonstrated antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects in vitro and in vivo, reducing ROS levels, inhibiting apoptosis, reprogramming macrophage polarization, and improving skin flap survival rates.
population_specificity: Animal model (specific species not mentioned) and in vitro cellular models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of VxFe3-xO4 magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs) for reactive oxygen species (ROS) production and heating in combination with photothermal, photodynamic, and magnetic fluid hyperthermia therapies.
results_summary: The study found that VxFe3-xO4 MNPs exhibited enhanced MFH and ROS-production capabilities, with a measured ˙OH-adduct concentration of up to 2300 nM and power absorption values of up to 1000 W g-1. Vanadium incorporation lowered magnetic anisotropy and acted as an electron buffer, improving performance compared to similarly-sized ferrite MNPs.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study using gel matrix emulating cytosol viscosity)
effective_dosage: 0.5 wt% MNPs under AC magnetic field amplitude of 65 mT and frequency of 350 kHz

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the standardized ileal digestible (SID) Valine to Lysine ratio required to optimize growth in weaned piglets while reducing dietary protein content.
results_summary: The study found that a 0.70 SID Val:Lys ratio maximized growth performance (ADFI, ADG, and G:F) in piglets, with higher ratios not significantly improving outcomes. Plasma Valine levels increased linearly with dietary Val:Lys, while other amino acids showed varied responses.
population_specificity: Weaned piglets weighing 8 kg, housed individually.
effective_dosage: Graded levels of crystalline L-Valine to achieve SID Val:Lys ratios of 0.58, 0.62, 0.66, 0.70, 0.74, and 0.78.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a vanadium-based MOF (V/BP-MOF) as an adsorbent for Congo Red dye and as an antimicrobial agent in wastewater treatment.
results_summary: The study found that V/BP-MOF achieved 94% adsorption of Congo Red under optimal conditions and demonstrated strong antimicrobial activity, particularly against Escherichia coli, with MIC and MBC values of 4 μg/mL and 2 μg/mL, respectively.
population_specificity: Common bacterial strains in wastewater.
effective_dosage: Not specified for human consumption; antimicrobial concentrations were 4 μg/mL (MIC) and 2 μg/mL (MBC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if in-situ hydrogen plasma treatment (HPT) could improve the photoelectric properties of vanadium oxide (V2Ox) film and the c-Si/V2Ox interface for solar cell applications.
results_summary: The study found that HPT increased O vacancy density in V2Ox and H bonds at the c-Si/V2Ox interface, reducing contact resistivity and improving passivation properties, achieving a power conversion efficiency of close to 23%. The results highlight V2Ox's potential as a stable hole selective contact for photovoltaics.
population_specificity: p-type crystalline silicon solar cells

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a mixed-valence vanadium-doped scaffold to simultaneously inhibit osteosarcoma recurrence and promote bone regeneration.
results_summary: The study found that mixed-valence vanadium species sustainably released from the scaffold enhanced BMSC proliferation, osteogenic differentiation, and mineralization while inducing tumor cell death via ROS generation and GSH depletion. In vivo results showed effective tumor suppression and bone regeneration in rats.
population_specificity: Rat model (in vivo) and bone marrow mesenchymal stem cells (BMSCs) and UMR-106 cells (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the stability, antiproliferative activity, and therapeutic potential of new oxovanadium(V) Schiff base-catecholate complexes for intratumoral glioblastoma treatment.
results_summary: The newly synthesized [VO(3-tBuHSHED)(TIPCAT)] complex demonstrated enhanced stability (t1/2 ~4.5 h) and strong antiproliferative activity (IC50 ~1.5 µM) in T98G glioblastoma cells, outperforming the lead compound [VO(HSHED)(DTB)]. Structural modifications improved stability, hydrophobicity, and steric bulk, with non-toxic degradation byproducts.
population_specificity: T98G glioblastoma cells and SVG p12 normal glial cells (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether structural transformations in vanadium carbide MXenzymes (TVMz) could enhance catalytic efficiency and oxidative stress in the tumor microenvironment for improved multimodal tumor therapy.
results_summary: The engineered HTVMz exhibited good stability, generated a thermal effect under NIR-II laser irradiation, and transformed into ultra-small vanadium oxide nanozymes (VOx), which amplified oxidative stress, disrupted redox homeostasis, and synergistically promoted tumor cell death via multiple therapeutic pathways.
population_specificity: Tumor microenvironment (in vitro or in vivo not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the mechanisms of DNA damage caused by vanadium trioxide (V2O3) and the associated cellular response pathways in human lymphocytes.
results_summary: V2O3 caused DNA damage through oxidized bases, increased ATM protein expression, and upregulated mRNA levels of Mt-1 and DNA repair genes (OGG1, APE1, Ku70, Ku80), suggesting repair via BER and NHEJ pathways.
population_specificity: Primary cultures of human lymphocytes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antitumor effects of vanadium dioxide nanoparticles (VSB NPs) by inducing ferroptosis and pyroptosis in tumor cells through redox regulation.
results_summary: VSB NPs effectively consumed glutathione (GSH) and induced toxic hydroxyl radicals (·OH) and singlet oxygen (1O2), leading to ferroptosis. Additionally, nanoparticle degradation activated NLRP3 inflammasomes, causing pyroptosis, and near-infrared light further enhanced these effects.
population_specificity: Tumor cells (in vitro or animal model implied, not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of V-Cur, a Vanadium(IV)-curcumin complex, in mitigating LPS-induced neuroinflammation and amyloid aggregation compared to curcumin alone.
results_summary: V-Cur more effectively disrupted LPS-induced overexpression of APP and in vitro aggregation of human insulin than curcumin, and it reduced iNOS levels and inflammation markers (IL-1β and TNF-α) more significantly.
population_specificity: Rat primary neurons and microglia in co-culture.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if combining vanadium complexes with olive leaf extracts could reduce vanadium's toxicity while enhancing its hypoglycemic effects.
results_summary: The study found that olive leaf extracts reduced the toxicity of vanadium compounds and significantly increased glucose uptake in human adipocyte cell lines, suggesting a synergistic effect. Immunocytochemical assays indicated GLUT4 transporter translocation may be involved in this mechanism.
population_specificity: Human colon fibroblasts and differentiated human adipocyte cell lines (in vitro).
effective_dosage: Not specified (different amounts of olive leaf extract mixed with vanadium complexes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the cardioprotective potential of Tectochrysin (TEC) against Vanadium (VAN)-induced cardiotoxicity in rats by examining biochemical and histological profiles.
results_summary: VAN exposure caused severe oxidative stress, inflammation, and apoptosis in cardiac tissues, significantly disrupting biochemical and structural integrity. TEC treatment effectively mitigated these adverse effects by regulating oxidative stress, inflammation, and apoptosis markers.
population_specificity: Male Sprague Dawley rats
effective_dosage: VAN (1.5 mg/kg), TEC (2.5 mg/kg), administered via oral gavage

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vanadium, in combination with glutaminase inhibitors, could disrupt colorectal cancer's energy metabolism and enhance treatment efficacy.
results_summary: Vanadium effectively inhibited glucose metabolism in colorectal cancer cells and synergized with glutaminase inhibitors to disrupt energy dependency, eradicating 33% of tumors in mice and enhancing anti-PD1 immunotherapy.
population_specificity: Colorectal cancer (CRC) cells and preclinical mouse models.
interactions: Synergistic effect with glutaminase inhibitors (BPTES) and anti-PD1 immunotherapy noted.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the performance of an all-vanadium-based lithium-ion battery using hierarchical micro-nano yolk-shell structures of V2O5 and V2O3 as cathode and anode materials.
results_summary: The hierarchical micro-nano yolk-shell V2O5 cathode demonstrated higher capacities than bulk V2O5 and commercial cathodes at various current densities. The full battery exhibited good cycle performance at 0.1C and stable charge/discharge abilities at large current densities, attributed to low impedance and pseudocapacitance-dominated lithium storage.
population_specificity: Not applicable (material science study, no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vanadium single-atoms (SAV) could serve as an effective artificial peroxidase for highly sensitive and selective carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) immunoassays.
results_summary: The study found that SAV exhibited superior peroxidase-like activity, enabling ultrasensitive CEA detection with a linear range of 0.03-10 ng/mL and a low detection limit of 0.335 ng/mL. The immunoassay demonstrated high precision, reproducibility, and specificity, outperforming traditional enzyme-based methods.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study, likely serum samples).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of vanadium complexes in photodynamic therapy (PDT) for cancer treatment, focusing on mitochondrial targeting, photodynamic efficiency, and cytotoxic effects.
results_summary: The study highlights vanadium's coordination flexibility, insulin-mimetic effects, lipid-lowering properties, and promising antitumor activities, positioning it as an effective agent in PDT due to its unique redox properties and biological activity. Mitochondria-targeting vanadium complexes show potential for selective ROS generation and apoptosis induction in cancer cells.
population_specificity: Not specified (theoretical/minireview focus)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether silicon (Si) could mitigate vanadium (V) toxicity in pepper plants by enhancing polyamine metabolism and reducing oxidative stress.
results_summary: Silicon application reduced vanadium content in leaves and roots, improved polyamine levels, enhanced enzyme activity (NR, PEPC, MDH), preserved PSII integrity, and reduced oxidative stress markers (EL, H2O2, MDA) in pepper plants under vanadium stress.
population_specificity: Pepper plants (Capsicum annuum)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a new electrocatalyst (CoMoO4@GF) to enhance the performance of vanadium redox flow batteries (VRFBs) by improving the kinetics of vanadium redox reactions.
results_summary: The study found that the CoMoO4@GF electrode significantly improved the energy efficiency of VRFBs by 19.14% at 200 mA cm-2 and demonstrated excellent stability over 350 cycles at 150 mA cm-2, indicating enhanced electrocatalytic activity and durability for vanadium redox reactions.
population_specificity: Not applicable (study focused on battery performance, not human or animal subjects).
study_duration: Not applicable (study measured performance over 350 charge-discharge cycles).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to demonstrate the topochemical reduction of α-V2O5 to produce metastable vanadium oxide phases with tunable oxygen vacancies and tin incorporation, exploring their optoelectronic and magnetic functionalities.
results_summary: The study successfully produced metastable vanadium oxide phases with high oxygen vacancy (>6%) and tin incorporation (>3.5%), showing tunable electronic properties through compensation doping. Electrical conductance increased with SnCl2 concentration and treatment time, indicating enhanced free electron density in the lattice.
population_specificity: Not applicable (material science study, no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the biogeochemical transformation of Vanadium (V) and Iron (Fe) in contaminated soil, focusing on microbial-mediated processes and the impact of organic amendments on V(V) release and reduction.
results_summary: Soil flooding reduced toxic reducible V while increasing less toxic oxidizable V. Glucose and straw temporarily increased V(V) release but eventually promoted its reduction, while biochar moderated V(V) release. Specific bacteria were identified as key players in Fe(III) reduction and V(V) transformation.
population_specificity: V-contaminated paddy soil (environmental study, no human subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (organic amendments: glucose, straw, biochar).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of pentavalent vanadium (V(V)) on the performance of electroactive biofilms (EABs) in microbial fuel cells (MFCs) and its bioreduction potential.
results_summary: Increasing V(V) concentrations (0-100 mg/L) reduced voltage output, power densities, and electrochemical performance in MFCs. V(V) acted as an electron acceptor with an 83.16% reduction yield at 25 mg/L, while key electron transfer indicators declined significantly at higher concentrations.
population_specificity: Electroactive biofilms (EABs) with Shewanella putrefaciens in microbial fuel cells (MFCs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic and toxic effects of organic vanadium salts and highlight the potential of vanadium complexes, including a novel dioxidovanadium complex, in managing hyperglycemia-associated complications.
results_summary: Vanadium demonstrated promising anti-diabetic efficacy in cell culture and animal studies by improving glucose management in key organs, but organic vanadium was considered toxic due to accumulation. Synthesized vanadium complexes were explored to mitigate toxicity while retaining therapeutic benefits.
population_specificity: Cell culture and animal models (specific species not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining platinum (Pt) with a V/CeO2 catalyst could enhance its catalytic performance for low-temperature oxidation of chlorinated volatile organic compounds (CVOCs), particularly under humid conditions.
results_summary: The study found that PtV/CeO2 achieved 90% CO2 yield at 318 °C and maintained excellent catalytic activity for 15 hours after water vapor injection. The formation of Pt-O-V bonds improved redox ability and mineralization, while Pt's dissociative activation of H2O enhanced water resistance.
population_specificity: Industrial exhaust gas treatment (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of microbial-induced phosphate precipitation (MIPP) on the behavior of heavy metals, including Cd, Cu, Pb, and Zn, in vanadium tailing slags with and without soil mixing.
results_summary: MIPP effectively immobilized Cd (43.41% under optimal parameters in 7 days) and improved performance when slags were covered with soil. However, DTPA-Cu, Zn, and Pb contents increased after MIPP treatment, while leaching tests showed reduced Cd²⁺, Pb²⁺, Ca²⁺, Mg²⁺, and Al³⁺ concentrations but no significant change in Cu²⁺ and Zn²⁺.
population_specificity: Vanadium tailing slags (environmental remediation context)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-inflammatory effects of silibinin and its mechanisms in mitigating vanadium pentoxide (V2O5)-induced pulmonary inflammation in mice.
results_summary: Silibinin significantly reduced inflammatory cell infiltration, pro-inflammatory cytokine expression, and suppressed key inflammatory pathways (MAPK, NF-κB, NLRP3 inflammasome) in V2O5-induced lung injury. It also lowered white blood cell counts, demonstrating potent anti-inflammatory effects.
population_specificity: Eight-week-old male BALB/c mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how carbon structural characteristics derived from walnut shells influence vanadium redox reactions in battery electrodes.
results_summary: The study found that carbonization temperatures up to 800 °C enhanced redox reactions for V2+/V3+ and VO2+/VO2+ couples, with specific oxygen and nitrogen sites in the carbon structure catalyzing V3+ oxidation. The V3+/VO2+ couple was limited by slow kinetics but occurred on selective surface sites.
population_specificity: Not applicable (materials science study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate vanadium-induced neurotoxicity and evaluate the neuroprotective effects of ZA-II-05 in mitigating these effects.
results_summary: Vanadium exposure reduced nuclear presence and mitochondrial content in *C. elegans*, indicating oxidative stress, while co-treatment with ZA-II-05 reversed these effects, preserving cellular integrity and neuronal function.
population_specificity: *Caenorhabditis elegans* (synchronized young adult worms)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to enhance the electrochemical performance and stability of Vanadium pentoxide (V2O5) for use in electrochromic supercapacitors by developing copper vanadium oxide yolk-shell microspheres (CVO) and CVO/NVO composites.
results_summary: The study found that CVO/NVO composites significantly improved specific capacitance (39.2 mF cm-2), cyclic stability (84% retention after 7500 cycles), and energy storage capacity (18.4 mF·cm-2 with 89% retention after 10,000 cycles), along with vivid color changes (ΔE* = 37), outperforming most previously reported V2O5-based electrochromic supercapacitors.
population_specificity: Not applicable (material science study, no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve the performance of vanadium redox flow batteries by optimizing carbon felt pretreatment methods and introducing noble metal catalysts.
results_summary: Carbon felt treated at 500°C for 2 hours showed the best performance, with the longest charge/discharge time and lowest resistance. Catalyst-introduced carbon felt without PTFE binder exhibited larger surface area, higher conductivity, and superior cell performance compared to PTFE-mixed samples.
population_specificity: Not applicable (study focused on battery components, not human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of deep-sea microbial communities in removing vanadium (V) and cadmium (Cd) from industrial wastewater through bioreduction, biosorption, and biomineralization.
results_summary: The study found that the microbial community achieved 86.32% removal efficiency for V5+ and 59.13% for Cd2+ under optimal conditions, with glucose oxidation accelerating V(V) reduction to V(IV) and Cd(II) forming precipitates like cadmium hydroxide and carbonate. Functional groups on microbial cell surfaces played a key role in adsorption.
population_specificity: Deep-sea microbial communities from hydrothermal vent sediments.
effective_dosage: V5+ concentration of 300 mg/L, Cd2+ concentration of 40 mg/L.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to enhance the recovery/extraction of vanadium from synthetic wastewater using an emulsion liquid membrane (ELM) system while improving emulsion stability for industrial applications.
results_summary: The study achieved 99.6% vanadium recovery in 3 minutes using Fe2O3 nanoparticles and an ionic liquid, significantly improving emulsion stability and reducing leakage to 16% after 3 days.
population_specificity: Synthetic wastewater (laboratory setting)
effective_dosage: 0.01% (w/w) Fe2O3 NPs in the internal phase and 5% (v/v) [OMIM]PF6 ionic liquid in the oil phase
study_duration: 3 minutes for extraction, stability assessed over 3 days

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an efficient method for extracting vanadium from metallurgical residues using an enhanced leaching process with O3-catalyzed ultrasonic treatment in a low-concentration sulfuric acid system.
results_summary: The study found that combining O3 and ultrasonic treatment increased vanadium leaching rates by 46.7%, with hydroxyl radicals (·OH) being the most effective active species for disrupting silicate inclusions. The process reduced activation energy by 20.19% compared to ultrasonic treatment alone.
population_specificity: Metallurgical residues (not human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vanadium recovered from industrial waste could be used to create efficient ternary vanadate-based photocatalysts for water remediation.
results_summary: The ternary vanadate-based photocatalysts (BVO/IVO/AVO) demonstrated enhanced photocatalytic activity, outperforming binary and pristine counterparts in degrading organic dyes, antibiotics, reducing Cr(VI), and bacterial inactivation. The study highlights a feasible method for recycling industrial vanadium waste into high-value photocatalysts.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro/environmental study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a modified vanadium carbide MXene nanosheet (L-V2C) for improved photothermal performance and theranostic capabilities in cancer treatment.
results_summary: The study found that surface-modified L-V2C nanosheets, combined with MnOx coating, demonstrated high photothermal efficiency, glutathione consumption, and Fenton-like reaction catalysis, leading to effective tumor oxidative damage and immunogenic cell death. The nanoplatform (LVM-PEG) showed excellent anticancer efficiency and multimodal imaging guidance.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or preclinical study implied by abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize and characterize a stable vanadium methylidene complex and explore its reactivity.
results_summary: The study successfully isolated a stable vanadium methylidene complex, confirmed its terminal nature via structural and spectroscopic analysis, and demonstrated its reactivity with H3COTf to release ethylene. The complex also activated dinitrogen in the absence of a ylide.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro chemical study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the life cycle greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions of vanadium recovery from petcoke-based fly ash and compare it with other production pathways.
results_summary: The study found that vanadium recovery from petcoke fly ash generates about twice the life cycle GHG emissions compared to production from vanadium titano-magnetite ore and bitumen upgrading spent catalyst, with 66% of emissions being direct. The process GHG emissions from fly ash decarbonization were the largest contributor.
population_specificity: Not applicable (environmental impact study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a graphitic carbon nitride-enhanced vanadium ferrite (VFe2O4@g-C3N4) as a photocatalyst for degrading antibiotics (sulfamethoxazole, ciprofloxacin, and erythromycin) in water.
results_summary: VFe2O4@g-C3N4 demonstrated high degradation efficiency, achieving complete removal of sulfamethoxazole (100%) and significant removal of ciprofloxacin (94%) and erythromycin (90%). The photocatalyst was stable and reusable, maintaining over 90% regeneration capacity after 10 cycles.
population_specificity: Aqueous solutions containing antibiotics (sulfamethoxazole, ciprofloxacin, erythromycin).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how varying concentrations of alkylammonium cations affect the interlayer spacing of hybrid bilayered vanadium oxides (BVOs) and their electrochemical performance in lithium-ion cells.
results_summary: The study found that increasing alkylammonium cation concentrations expanded interlayer spacing but reduced specific capacities due to obstructed intercalation sites and hindered Li+ ion transport. Greater layer separation also led to faster capacity decay by facilitating active material dissolution into the electrolyte.
population_specificity: Not applicable (material science study, no human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (chemical concentrations varied, but no dosage in traditional supplement terms).
study_duration: Not specified (electrochemical cycling duration not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neurotoxic effects of vanadium pentoxide (V2O5) alone and in combination with manganese (MnCl2) in an animal model, focusing on olfactory and nigral systems.
results_summary: The study found that vanadium exposure, especially in combination with manganese, led to significant neurotoxic effects, including decreased olfactory bulb weight, reduced dopamine levels, increased oxidative stress, and locomotor deficits. Co-exposure produced the most severe deficits, suggesting synergistic neurotoxicity.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice
effective_dosage: V2O5 (182 µg) three times a week

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether melatonin (ME) treatment could mitigate vanadium (V)-induced phytotoxicity in muskmelon seedlings.
results_summary: Vanadium toxicity significantly impaired seedling growth, photosynthesis, and antioxidant activity, while melatonin treatment reduced V accumulation, oxidative damage, and improved growth, photosynthesis, and antioxidant gene expression.
population_specificity: Muskmelon seedlings grown hydroponically.
effective_dosage: Vanadium (40 mg L-1), melatonin (100 μmol L-1).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a nanomedicine (EVP) combining vanadium sulfate (VOSO4) with other compounds for synergistic tumor treatment via photothermal therapy (PTT) and chemodynamic therapy (CDT).
results_summary: EVP demonstrated potent tumor inhibition by downregulating heat shock proteins (HSPs) and enhancing hydroxyl radical production via a Fenton-like reaction, overcoming pH limitations for CDT. In vitro and in vivo experiments confirmed its biocompatibility and efficacy.
population_specificity: Tumor models (in vitro and in vivo, specific organism not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the anti-diabetic and antioxidant effects of the oxidovanadium(IV) complex (Vox2) in rats with STZ-induced diabetes.
results_summary: Vox2, especially at 100 mg/kg in combination with insulin, significantly reduced blood glucose levels (3.4 times decrease) and increased pancreatic GSH levels (2.5 times) without causing gastrointestinal discomfort, diarrhea, or hepatic/renal toxicity.
population_specificity: Rats with streptozotocin (STZ)-induced diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the influence of structural and functional groups on vanadium redox reactions at carbon surfaces in flow batteries.
results_summary: The study found that hydrophilic functionalities enhanced half-cell performance in non-activated carbon felt but not in thermally activated felt, where thermal treatment-generated active sites outperformed functional groups and their introduction reduced long-term stability.
population_specificity: Carbon-based electrodes in flow batteries (not human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of titanium carbide (Ti3C2Tx) MXene coating on carbon electrodes for improving the performance of vanadium redox flow batteries by enhancing the V(ii)/V(iii) reaction and reducing hydrogen evolution side reactions.
results_summary: The study found that MXene-coated electrodes showed sharper electrochemical peaks, a higher reaction rate (5.61 × 10-4 cm s-1), and stable discharge capacity over 100 cycles, with significantly improved voltage and energy efficiency compared to untreated or thermally treated electrodes.
population_specificity: Not applicable (study focused on electrode materials, not human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of biochar in reducing vanadium (V) concentration in wastewater under specific reaction conditions.
results_summary: The study found that biochar reduced vanadium (V) concentration by 96.1% under optimal conditions (mass ratio of biochar to vanadium of 5.4, 90 °C, 60 min, and 10 g/L H2SO4). Response surface methodology confirmed that H2SO4 concentration and biochar-to-vanadium ratio had the greatest influence on reduction efficiency.
population_specificity: Wastewater containing high concentrations of vanadium (V).
effective_dosage: Mass ratio of biochar to vanadium of 5.4, 10 g/L H2SO4.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of aggressive steroid therapy in treating severe chemical pneumonitis caused by vanadium pentoxide inhalation.
results_summary: The patient showed dramatic improvement in pulmonary symptoms and chest X-ray findings after receiving aggressive steroid therapy, suggesting it may shorten the disease course. The study highlights the potential benefit of early steroid treatment despite infection risks.
population_specificity: A healthy man with severe chemical pneumonitis due to vanadium pentoxide inhalation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the metabolic response of human bronchial epithelial cells to low-level Vanadium pentoxide (V+5) exposure and its potential toxicity.
results_summary: V+5 exposure caused extensive metabolic changes, altered mitochondrial structure and function, and decreased E-cadherin levels, suggesting potential toxicity and EMT activation without cell death. High-resolution metabolomics was effective in detecting these low-level effects.
population_specificity: Human bronchial epithelial BEAS-2B cells

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (AMF) in vanadium (V) removal in constructed wetlands and elucidate the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that AMF-inoculated reed plants showed higher vanadium removal (60%-98%) compared to non-inoculated controls (40%-82%), with the most significant effects at low influent V concentrations. AMF inoculation also increased plant size, V tissue concentration, and biological accumulation factors.
population_specificity: Reed plants (Phragmites australis) in constructed wetland columns.
effective_dosage: Three influent V concentrations: low (0.50 mg L-1), medium (1.14 mg L-1), and high (1.52 mg L-1).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of titanium vanadium oxide (3%-BVT1) as a photocatalyst for degrading diclofenac in water under visible light.
results_summary: The study found that 3%-BVT1 achieved 80.7% diclofenac degradation with a reaction rate significantly higher than commercial Degussa P25, retaining 74.1% efficiency over five cycles. Oxidative species like •OH and O2•- contributed to enhanced photocatalysis, with minimal interference from phosphates and nitrates.
population_specificity: Aqueous diclofenac solution (not human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the electrocatalytic performance of a new high-entropy oxide (HEO) nanoparticle for vanadium redox flow batteries (VRFBs).
results_summary: The HEO-750 catalyst demonstrated superior electrocatalytic activity for V3+/V2+ and VO2+/VO2+ redox couples, achieving high Coulombic, voltage, and energy efficiencies at different current densities with no degradation over 500 charge-discharge cycles. The improved performance was attributed to the fluorite structure, high surface area, wettability, and oxygen vacancies.
population_specificity: Not applicable (materials science study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the technologies for regeneration and recycling of spent vanadium-titanium SCR catalysts to promote resource recovery and environmental sustainability.
results_summary: The review summarizes current methods for recycling and high-efficiency recovery of valuable components from spent vanadium-titanium SCR catalysts and discusses future development directions for their recycling.
population_specificity: Not applicable (review paper, no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of repurposing non-oncology-approved drugs by complexing them with vanadium to develop novel anticancer treatments.
results_summary: The study identified several vanadium complexes (e.g., metformin-decavanadate, vanadium-bisphosphonates) with potential anticancer effects, though the precise mechanisms of action remain unclear. The parent drugs of these complexes, known for various medicinal properties, showed promise when combined with vanadium for cancer therapy.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing research).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate a tungstate zirconia (WZ) catalyst for improving the electrochemical performance of vanadium redox flow batteries (VRFBs).
results_summary: The WZ-22-650 catalyst demonstrated superior catalytic activity for VO2+/VO2+ redox couples, achieving high voltage efficiency (87.76%) and energy efficiency (83.94%) at 80 mA cm-2, with maintained efficiency even at 160 mA cm-2. The catalyst's robust anchoring of WOx to ZrO2 enhanced surface electroactive sites, improving VRFB performance.
population_specificity: Not applicable (materials science study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness and mechanisms of phosphoric acid-modified biochar (MLBC) in immobilizing and stabilizing vanadium (V) in contaminated soil.
results_summary: MLBC significantly reduced vanadium concentrations in short-term extractions (30 days) but showed slight to significant increases in long-term extractions (90 days). The 4% MLBC dosage demonstrated high durability in stabilizing vanadium under continuous acid exposure, with key factors being pH, available phosphorus, and soil organic matter.
population_specificity: Soil contaminated with exogenous vanadium.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuroprotective potential of vanadium in juvenile hydrocephalic mice by assessing its effects on motor and cerebellar cortices.
results_summary: Vanadium treatment improved motor ability and mitigated neurodegeneration and reactive astrogliosis in hydrocephalic mice, except at high doses where astrogliosis persisted. The study suggests vanadium has neuroprotective effects in hydrocephalus.
population_specificity: Juvenile hydrocephalic mice
effective_dosage: 0.15 mg/kg (low), 0.3 mg/kg (moderate), 3.0 mg/kg (high), administered intraperitoneally every 72 hours

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neuroprotective effects of ZA-II-05 against vanadium-induced neurotoxicity in hippocampal slices and live mice.
results_summary: Vanadium exposure caused significant cell death, demyelination, microgliosis, and neuronal loss in mice, while ZA-II-05 treatment reduced cellular death and preserved cellular integrity in hippocampal slices and brain regions.
population_specificity: Organotypic rat hippocampal slices and live mice (five dams, each with eight pups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether integrating vanadium (V) into a palladium (Pd)/C catalyst could enhance the catalytic reduction of chlorate (ClO3-) in water treatment.
results_summary: The study found that vanadium integration increased catalytic activity by 18-fold, with the VIII/IV redox cycle being the primary mechanism for ClO3- reduction. Toxic vanadium was immobilized post-reaction by pH adjustment for safe catalyst recycling.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on catalytic systems).
effective_dosage: Not specified (catalyst composition studied, not dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to design and optimize the composition and heat treatment parameters of high-molybdenum-vanadium high-speed steel for rolls to improve performance and stability.
results_summary: The study found that increasing molybdenum and vanadium content improved the steel's wear resistance, castability, and high-temperature red hardness. Simulation and experimental results confirmed optimal heat treatment parameters, achieving consistent performance.
population_specificity: Industrial tool steel applications (rolls)
effective_dosage: Not applicable (material composition: C2%, Mo7.0%, V7.0%, Si0.3%, Mn0.3%, Ni0.4%, Cr3.0%, balance iron)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and compare electrode treatments to reduce overvoltages and improve performance in vanadium redox flow batteries (VRFBs).
results_summary: The study reviewed over 70 electrode treatments, identifying thermal, plasma, electrochemical oxidation, CO2 treatments, and Bi, Ag, and Cu catalysts as the most promising for large-scale VRFBs. It also highlighted the need for standardization in testing and fundamental studies to understand charge transfer reactions.
population_specificity: Industrial and laboratory-scale applications of vanadium redox flow batteries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether V4C3 nanosheets could serve as an effective antioxidant for treating pulmonary fibrosis by targeting oxidative stress.
results_summary: V4C3 nanosheets demonstrated broad-spectrum, high-efficiency antioxidant capacity through multiple mechanisms, significantly alleviating bleomycin-induced pulmonary fibrosis in vivo by reducing ROS, inflammation, and restoring antioxidant defenses.
population_specificity: Animal model (bleomycin-induced pulmonary fibrosis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the molecular crosstalk between mitochondria-associated endoplasmic reticulum membranes (MAMs) and inflammation in duck hepatocytes exposed to Vanadium.
results_summary: Vanadium exposure caused cellular damage, oxidative stress, disruption of MAMs structure, calcium overload, and altered levels of inflammation-related factors, but inhibition of IP3R attenuated these effects.
population_specificity: Duck hepatocytes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Lemna aequinoctialis (lesser duckweed) in remediating vanadium from an organo-metallic contaminated medium.
results_summary: The study found that lesser duckweed removed 55.22% of vanadium from the contaminated medium, following first-order kinetics. The remediation was time-dependent and partial, with vanadium showing a high correlation coefficient (r² = 0.967).
population_specificity: Artificial surface wetland mesocosm (laboratory setting).
effective_dosage: Not specified (100 g fresh-weight duckweed per mesocosm).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the performance of lignin-derived carbon-modified electrodes in Vanadium redox flow batteries (VRFBs) for improved energy efficiency and power density.
results_summary: The study found that lignin-derived carbon-modified electrodes (Lignin-CF) significantly improved electrochemical activity, achieving high energy efficiency (83.3%) and voltage efficiency (85.0%) over 1000 cycles, along with a power density of 1053.2 mW cm-2, outperforming pristine and heated bare carbon felt.
population_specificity: Not applicable (study focused on battery electrodes, not human subjects).
study_duration: Over 16 days (1000 cycles at 100 mA cm-2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of vanadium-nitrogen-carbon materials as catalysts for the selective hydration of nitriles, specifically converting 2-cyanopyrazine to pyrazinamide.
results_summary: Vanadium-nitrogen-carbon materials successfully catalyzed the hydration of 2-cyanopyrazine to pyrazinamide with high substrate specificity. Additives with N and O atoms influenced the reaction due to competitive adsorption/coordination.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro chemical study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the stability, mechanisms of action, and anticancer potential of two Vanadium(V) complexes (1 and 2) in triple-negative human breast cancer cells.
results_summary: Both complexes showed high antiproliferative activity in MDA-MB-231 cells, but their mechanisms differed—complex 1 acted rapidly via passive diffusion and noncovalent binding to albumin, while complex 2's activity depended on decomposition products and oxygen reactions. Complex 1 was more stable and suitable for intratumoral delivery, whereas complex 2's efficacy was sensitive to hypoxic conditions and transferrin scavenging.
population_specificity: Triple-negative human breast cancer (MDA-MB-231) cells.
effective_dosage: IC50 values: 1.9 ± 0.2 μM (30 min) and 1.3 ± 0.2 μM (72 h) for complex 1; ≈12 μM (72 h) for complex 2.
study_duration: Short-term (30 min) and long-term (72 h) treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the genotoxic and cytotoxic potential of vanadium oxides (V2O4 and V2O3) in mouse bone marrow cells.
results_summary: The study found that all tested doses of vanadium compounds increased structural chromosomal aberrations and decreased the mitotic index, indicating genotoxic and cytotoxic effects. The results suggest that vanadium oxides induce chromosomal damage and disrupt cell division in mice.
population_specificity: Mouse bone marrow cells
effective_dosage: V2O4 at 4.7, 9.4, or 18.8 mg/kg; V2O3 at 4.22, 8.46, or 16.93 mg/kg (single intraperitoneal administration)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a vanadium-based MXene nanoplatform (VAB) for enhancing nanozyme catalytic/photothermal therapy in disrupting tumor redox homeostasis.
results_summary: The VAB nanoplatform demonstrated a remarkable anti-tumor effect by disrupting redox homeostasis, generating reactive oxygen species (ROS), and consuming glutathione. It also showed strong photothermal effects and improved peroxidase-like activity under near-infrared irradiation, while atovaquone release alleviated oxygen consumption and inhibited mitochondrial respiration.
population_specificity: Tumor cells (in vitro or animal model, not specified for humans).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of different electrode treatments on the performance and long-term operation of Vanadium redox flow battery (VRFB) electrodes.
results_summary: The study found significant differences in wettability, sorption/desorption behavior, and electrochemical performance of treated carbon felts, with bulk saturation ranging from 8% to 96% and catalytic activities varying post-treatment. Morphology changes were also observed, highlighting the impact of treatments on material properties.
population_specificity: Carbon felts used in VRFB electrodes (not human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the potential of vanadium compounds in treating Alzheimer's disease (AD) by reviewing experimental research and highlighting current limitations.
results_summary: The abstract suggests vanadium compounds show promise in glucose metabolism regulation and potential applications in AD treatment, but it also notes limitations in current research.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals with Alzheimer's disease (AD) and potential links to type-3 diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a high-efficiency vanadium-based dehydrogenation catalyst by constructing pure V3+ species on γ-Al2O3 to improve isobutene yield and selectivity.
results_summary: The study found that the V3+ species enhanced dehydrogenation activity and formed an ideal V3+-O/S acid-base pair, achieving a 56.9 wt% isobutene yield with minimal side reactions and coke deposition (2.5 wt% over 8.5 hours). However, the valence state of vanadium was affected, increasing inert V4+ species over time.
population_specificity: Not applicable (catalyst study, not human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of BaTiO3 and PbTiO3 incorporation into vanadium borate glass matrices on electrical conductivity and crystalline phase formation.
results_summary: The study found that electrical conductivity of glass-ceramic nanocomposites increased significantly (up to 6 orders of magnitude) with higher BaTiO3 content, attributed to increased crystalline phases and V ion pair concentrations. Activation energy values also rose with BaTiO3 content.
population_specificity: Not applicable (material science study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of vanadium disulfide (VS2) nanosheets as a bioactive vanadium source and gas donor for activating cancer immunotherapy in combination with immune-checkpoint blockade therapy.
results_summary: VS2-PEG demonstrated efficient glutathione depletion and hydrogen sulfide release, leading to lysosome escape, reduced ATP synthesis, and Na+/K+ ATPase inhibition. Combined with α-PD-1, it significantly suppressed tumor growth and stimulated a strong antitumor immune response.
population_specificity: Tumor cells and tumor microenvironment (in vitro/in vivo study, no human subjects specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the mobilization, redistribution, and immobilization of vanadium (V) within vanadium‑titanium magnetite tailings during weathering.
results_summary: The study found that shallow tailings immobilized V more effectively than deep tailings, primarily through adsorption or precipitation by Fe (hydr)oxides. Over time, bioavailable V fractions were mineralized into residual V, reducing mobility and bioavailability, while additional V(V) promoted the formation of specific mineral phases like melanovanadite and chromium vanadium oxide.
population_specificity: Vanadium‑titanium magnetite tailings at different depths.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the chemical properties, hydrolytic stability, and anti-proliferative activity of new Vanadium complexes with pyridine-containing Schiff bases, particularly for potential use in treating glioblastoma.
results_summary: The study found that [VV O(SALIEP)(DTB)] exhibited significant anti-proliferative activity against human glioblastoma cells (T98G) with an IC50 of 6.7±0.9 μM, showing five times higher efficacy compared to non-cancerous human cells (HFF-1). The pyridine moiety improved hydrolytic stability and cellular uptake of the intact complex.
population_specificity: Human glioblastoma (T98G) and non-cancerous human (HFF-1) cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a recycling method for fly ash to recover vanadium pentoxide (V2O5) and nickel ferrite (NiFe2O4) using pyro-hydrometallurgical processes.
results_summary: The study achieved high vanadium recovery rates (91% in H2SO4, 95.6% in HCl) and produced V2O5 with high purity (93% in sulfate, 98.5% in chloride media). The process demonstrated effective separation of vanadium from other metals, with minimal nickel dissolution.
population_specificity: Fly ash from heavy-oil-consuming Iranian power plants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a label-free electrochemical biosensor using vanadium disulfide (VS2) nanosheets for the specific detection of MMP-2 protein, a biomarker for cancers like prostate and breast cancer.
results_summary: The study successfully fabricated a biosensor using VS2 nanosheets, demonstrating high sensitivity (7.272 (ΔR/R)(ng ml)-1cm-2) and a low detection limit (0.138 fg ml-1) for MMP-2. The sensor was also highly selective against non-specific proteins.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a nanoplatform (PMVL) containing vanadium oxides could enhance ferroptosis in tumor cells by regulating glycometabolism and triggering immune activation.
results_summary: The study found that vanadium's mixed valence (VIV and VV) in PMVL induced ferroptosis through cyclic valence alteration, generating •OH for lipid peroxide accumulation and depleting GSH to deactivate GPX4. Additionally, lonidamine (LND) further strengthened ferroptosis by suppressing glycolysis and the pentose phosphate pathway, reducing GSH production and altering the tumor microenvironment.
population_specificity: Tumor cells (in vitro and in vivo models)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent progress in modifying carbonous felt electrodes to improve the performance of vanadium redox flow batteries (VRFBs).
results_summary: The study found that increasing surface area and active sites are key factors in enhancing the performance of carbonous felt electrodes, and it discussed various modification methods to improve vanadium redox reactions.
population_specificity: Not applicable (study focused on electrochemical systems, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize data on vanadium's neurological side effects and its potential role in neurodegenerative disorders, focusing on exposure levels in humans.
results_summary: The review suggests vanadium may play a role in neurodegenerative diseases due to its pro-oxidant effects, but the exact relationship at realistic human exposure levels remains unclear, highlighting the need for further epidemiological studies.
population_specificity: Humans, particularly those with neurodegenerative syndromes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the toxicity of vanadium (VCI3) in Allium cepa L. by examining its effects on germination, cytogenetic parameters, DNA damage, and biochemical markers.
results_summary: VCI3 exposure significantly reduced germination-related parameters, increased chromosomal abnormalities and DNA damage, and elevated oxidative stress markers. It also induced anatomical damages in root cells, with dose-dependent effects.
population_specificity: Allium cepa L. (onion) bulbs

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a tear-based MMP-9 antigen testing platform using vanadium disulfide nanowires for early detection of ocular inflammatory diseases.
results_summary: The biosensor demonstrated sub-femto level limits of detection (0.1344 fg/mL in PBS and 0.2746 fg/mL in artificial tear solution) and excellent precision when validated with ELISA using tear samples from healthy controls. The platform showed potential as a non-invasive diagnostic tool for ocular inflammation.
population_specificity: Healthy controls (five individuals)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the mechanisms of action of vanadium compounds against various parasites and assess their potential as therapeutic options.
results_summary: Vanadium compounds demonstrated a broad spectrum of activity against different parasites, suggesting potential as a treatment option, though specific efficacy details were not provided.
population_specificity: Parasitic infections (e.g., malaria, leishmaniasis, trypanosomiasis)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop vanadium vacancy-rich BiVO4 nanosheets to enhance reactive oxygen species (ROS) generation for improved cancer therapy via ultrasound-enhanced piezoelectric/sonodynamic therapy.
results_summary: The study found that vanadium vacancy-rich BiVO4 nanosheets significantly increased ROS yield under ultrasound excitation, improving oxidative stress in cancer cells and inhibiting their growth. Both computational and experimental results confirmed the enhanced sonodynamic effect due to cationic vacancy introduction.
population_specificity: Cancer cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop high-performance cathode materials (a-V2O5@CNTs) for aqueous zinc-ion batteries by leveraging the properties of amorphous vanadium oxide and carbon nanotubes.
results_summary: The a-V2O5@CNTs exhibited high specific capacity (480 mAh g-1 at 0.5 A g-1), good rate capability, and long-term stability (158 mAh g-1 at 30 A g-1 over 1000 cycles), demonstrating potential as an effective electrode material. The flexible pouch battery also showed outstanding flexibility and feasibility.
population_specificity: Not applicable (material science study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the structural-phase state and mechanical properties of a V-Cr-Ta-Zr alloy after combined thermomechanical and chemical-heat treatments.
results_summary: The combined treatment resulted in a composite structural-phase state with dispersion and substructural strengthening, forming a gradient grain structure stabilized by ZrO2 nanoparticles. This modification improved high-temperature strength and extended thermal stability up to 900°C, with potential cooperative dislocation-disclination mechanisms enhancing material accommodation under load.
population_specificity: Not applicable (material science study on alloy properties).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different calcination atmospheres on the therapeutic efficacy and biosafety of Fe-V-O (FVO) nanomaterials for tumor therapy.
results_summary: FVO nanomaterials prepared by argon calcination showed lower metallic valence state, higher near-infrared light absorption capacity, and significantly better biosafety and therapeutic efficacy (CDT/PTT) compared to those calcinated in air.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or preclinical study implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the influence of vanadium micro-alloying on the microstructural variation, residual austenite formation, and precipitation state in S355 steel grade subjected to double-pass welding thermal cycles.
results_summary: The study found that vanadium addition favored residual austenite formation, but the amount was insignificant to cause detrimental effects (less than 0.6%). High vanadium content (0.1 wt.%) led to the formation of vanadium-rich precipitates, mostly smaller than 15 nm.
population_specificity: S355 steel grade samples subjected to simulated double-pass welding thermal cycles.
effective_dosage: 0.1 wt.% vanadium (high content) and other unspecified lower amounts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of vanadium valence on enzyme activity in vanadium oxide nanozymes for tumor treatment, focusing on reactive oxygen species (ROS) production and glutathione (GSH) consumption.
results_summary: Vanadium oxide nanozyme-III (V4+) showed strong peroxidase and oxidase activities, effectively producing ROS and consuming GSH, while vanadium oxide nanozyme-I (V5+) exhibited catalase activity, alleviating tumor hypoxia. The optimized vanadium oxide nanozyme demonstrated excellent antitumor ability and high safety in cell and animal experiments.
population_specificity: Tumor models (cell and animal experiments)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of bioleaching using Acidithiobacillus ferrooxidans for recovering vanadium from vanadium-bearing smelting ash.
results_summary: The study found that Acidithiobacillus ferrooxidans effectively leached 41.9% of vanadium from smelting ash, with optimal conditions identified as 1% pulp density, 10% inoculum volume, initial pH of 1.8, and 3 Fe2+g/L. The bioleaching process transferred reducible, oxidizable, and acid-soluble fractions into the leaching liquor.
population_specificity: Vanadium-bearing smelting ash (not human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of Shewanella oneidensis MR-1 and oxalic acid in mediating vanadium (V) reduction and redistribution in tailing environments.
results_summary: The study found that oxalic acid enhanced microbial-mediated vanadium release from solid-phase, with significantly higher dissolved V concentrations in treated systems compared to controls. The combination of S. oneidensis MR-1 and oxalic acid also promoted the conversion of V2O5 to NaV6O15 in solid-state.
population_specificity: V-containing tailings and Fe/Mn oxide aggregates (environmental samples, not human or animal).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vanadium could protect hippocampal pyramidal neurons and improve learning and memory functions in juvenile hydrocephalic mice.
results_summary: Vanadium treatment significantly improved learning abilities (shorter escape latencies) and partially reversed memory impairments in hydrocephalic mice, with dose-dependent protective effects on hippocampal pyramidal neurons and reduced astrocytic activation.
population_specificity: Juvenile hydrocephalic mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of vanadium-enriched yeast (VEY) supplementation on gene expression related to insulin signaling and clinical outcomes in obese type 2 diabetic patients.
results_summary: VEY supplementation significantly improved anthropometric indices, glycemic parameters, and insulin sensitivity, and modulated gene expression (MAPK, PTP1B, NFƘB) compared to placebo, but did not affect dietary intake, quality of life, or lipid profile.
population_specificity: Obese type 2 diabetic mellitus (T2DM) patients (n=44).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a green, sustainable method for removing vanadium from industrial effluents using microalgae and to utilize the produced biomass for biofuels.
results_summary: The study found that microalgae Chlorella sorokiniana SU1 and Picochlorum oklahomensis effectively removed vanadium (III) with a maximum removal of 25.5 mg L-1, and optimizing pH and temperature enhanced removal by 2-2.7 folds. The biomass and lipid yields were 3.0 g L-1 and 884.4 mg L-1, respectively.
population_specificity: Industrial effluents contaminated with vanadium (III).
effective_dosage: Not specified (study focused on removal capacity, not dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate associations between diverse sexual and gender identities and adolescent use of e-cigarettes, tobacco products, and cannabis vaping.
results_summary: The study found significant disparities in substance use behaviors among sexual and gender minority (SGM) youth, with higher prevalence and odds of e-cigarette, tobacco, and cannabis vaping compared to heterosexual and cisgender peers. Bisexual, pansexual, queer, asexual, nonbinary, genderfluid, genderqueer, and transgender or questioning students showed elevated risks.
population_specificity: Nationally representative sample of high school students in 2023.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the potential severity of EVALI (e-cigarette or vaping product use-associated lung injury) and its under-diagnosis due to limited awareness.
results_summary: The study reported a severe case of EVALI in a 19-year-old male, requiring ICU admission, intubation, and ECMO support, emphasizing the need for clinical suspicion in vaping users with sudden-onset respiratory symptoms.
population_specificity: 19-year-old male in Denmark with severe respiratory symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the performance and durability of a hybrid membrane (PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(1.0)) for vanadium redox flow batteries (VRFBs) compared to a Cr-MOF incorporated Nafion membrane.
results_summary: The PHP@AMPSCr-MOF(1.0) membrane demonstrated superior performance with 97.5% Coulombic efficiency (CE) at 150 mA/cm² over 1500 cycles (650 h), while the NafionCr-MOF membrane showed deterioration after 800 cycles (360 h) with 94.5% CE. The hybrid membrane's effectiveness was attributed to synergized properties and hydrophilic proton-conducting channels.
population_specificity: Not applicable (study focused on battery membranes, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the challenges in diagnosing and treating EVALI, particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic, and investigate the toxicity of vaping products.
results_summary: The study found that EVALI is linked to THC and vitamin E acetate use, lacks specific diagnostic biomarkers, and is often misdiagnosed as COVID-19 or pneumonia. Cases of EVALI declined after the removal of vitamin E acetate but still occur, necessitating further research on diagnostic markers and vaping toxicity.
population_specificity: Middle and high school students in the United States, with a focus on pediatric patients misdiagnosed with COVID-19 or pneumonia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effectiveness of a mHealth program and nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) for vaping cessation in young adults.
